review.title: Sorting out typicality with the inverse moment matrix SOS polynomial
review.abstract: We study a surprising phenomenon related to the representation of a cloud of data points using polynomials. We start with the previously unnoticed empirical observation that, given a collection (a cloud) of data points, the sublevel sets of a certain distinguished polynomial capture the shape of the cloud very accurately. This distinguished polynomial is a sum-of-squares (SOS) derived in a simple manner from the inverse of the empirical moment matrix. In fact, this SOS polynomial is directly related to orthogonal polynomials and the Christoffel function. This allows to generalize and interpret extremality properties of orthogonal polynomials and to provide a mathematical rationale for the observed phenomenon. Among diverse potential applications, we illustrate the relevance of our results on a network intrusion detection task for which we obtain performances similar to existing dedicated methods reported in the literature.

sections.text: Remember that s (d) = (p + d) is the number of p-variable monomials of degree to d. Estimating the coefficients of Qµ, d has computational costs that are only linear from the number of points n. The costs of evaluating Qµ, d are constant in terms of the number of points n. This is an important contrast to nuclear or distance-based methods (such as nearest neighbors and a class SVM) for density estimation or outlier detection, as they normally require at least O (n2) operations to evaluate the model [1]. Furthermore, this is well suited for online settings where the inverse moment matrix can be calculated.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments on network intrusion datasets
sections.text: In addition to its own mathematical interest, Theorem 1 can be used for various purposes. For example, the sub-level sets of Qµ, d, and in particular {x-Rp: Qµ, d (x) ≤ (p + d)}, can be used to encode a cloud of dots in a simple and compact form. However, in this section we will focus on another potential application in anomalous metrics. Empirical results described in Section 4 suggest that the polynomial Qµ, d can be used to detect outliers in a collection of real vectors by taking the appropriate empirical metrics. This is supported by the results presented in Section 4. We select the KDD-Cup 99 Network Dataset (available at [11]), which consists of network connection data describing whether they correspond to normal traffic or network interference.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and future work
sections.text: We presented empirical results with a mathematical intuition regarding the subsets of the inverse moment matrix SOS-polynomial. This opens up many potential subjects of investigation. • Similarities with maximum probability. • Statistics in the context of empirical processes. • Relationship between a density and its inverse moment matrix SOS-polynomial. Assymptotics as the degree increases. • Connections with computational geometry and non-Gaussian integrals. • Mathematically traceable extensions in higher dimensions.
